information.title: Boomtown
information.description: BoomTown is an online, social strategy game where players assume control of a mcc and a standing army of soldier and wage war against other faction, mining resource and crafting equipment to give them an advantage.

feature.title: Kova

goals.goal: Provide context for most or all of the player's actions within the game

feature.background:
The year is 2106. Humankind sent probes into deep, unexplored space, only to find it absent interesting or useful planets, with the exception of , a planet devoid of life, but rich in consumable resources. kovanite, a mineral not found on Earth, proved to be invaluable in the manufacture of mankind's most advanced technology, and many large companies rushed equipment and manpower to the planet in order to extract it. The surface deposits ran out, causing companies to establish mining facilities, which naturally became points of conflict. Almost a century later, three organizations control most of the planet, and wage an all out war against each other to claim the richest mineral deposits, intent on mining valuable resource from beneath the planetâ€™s surface and utilizing them for their own ends.
Players take on the role of a military commander, in command of an immense Mobile Command Center and a small army of soldier within, tasked by their chosen faction to secure kovanite and transport it back to faction_headquarters, and hinder enemy faction from doing so wherever possible.
feature.implementation: is the planet upon which the game takes place. From the moment players launch the game, even if they aren't logged in, the setting of should permeate the experience. They should feel as though they have suddenly become part of this world, as though their presence on is immediately requested. An unregistered player should be plasterd with "Visit " propoganda from each faction, enticing them to "join the fight for kovanite."
feature.impact: The player will always need a fictional reason, however unlikely or boring, to perform their actions in the game. Some players need more immersion than others, and since Boomtown is a two-dimensional game with limited graphics power behind it, the story and setting behind the game needs to be relatively substantial. A well thought out setting will give the player motivation behind their actions within the game, and a reason to continue hoping for their faction's success.

feature.title: Commander

goals.goal: Provide an overarching role that the player can assume
Provide an embodiment for the player within the game
Provide a means to represent one player to another player in a recognizable form

feature.background: Due to massive population growth on Earth, many able young men and women venture to setting to fight for one of the controlling faction with the promise of money and power. With the advent of clone soldier and remote battlefield control, commanding an army on setting is relatively safe, providing a very effective lure for the organizations needing substantial manpower to secure their place on the planet.
feature.implementation: The is the representation of the player within the game. The player creates a " card" when they first sign up, providing a standard, recongizable way to represent their individualism to themselves and other players. The card includes a photo provided by the player, as well as a visible rank insignia so other players viewing the card can instantly tell what rank the is. The controls a single mcc at a time, and a fights for a single faction. A commander doesn't have 'levels' like in normal MMOs, but instead attains rank.
feature.impact: All actions the player wants to take will be 'carried out' by their . This serves to separate the player from their counterpart in the game, just in case future versions include the ability to use more than one . The also helps other players identify the player, because each will be unique in name and appearance (both of which are provided by the player).

feature.title: Rank

goals.goal: Provide a way for players to distinguish between newer players and older players
Provide another incentive for players to perform actions in the game and gain experience for their commander

feature.implementation:
A commander's is essentially an identifier letting other players know how long the commander has been playing. The should always be visible any time the commander's information is displayed on screen, and a history of the
and when the commander achieved them should be kept for each commander.
Additionally, many things the player may attempt to do will require a certain . Certain actions or buttons may be unavailable, grayed out, etc. and should display a "You must achieve X before you can do this" message to the player.
The commander gains new
by gaining experience.
feature.impact:
are mostly a way to easily tell powerful players from beginning players.
will also be an easy, tiered way to keep beginning players from performing certain actions meant for more experienced players.

feature.title: Experience

goals.goal: Provide a gauge of a player's progress and reward them for their actions
Provide an easy way to grant rank after certain variable lengths of play time

feature.implementation:
The player should always be able to tell how much their commander currently has, whether it be a little progress bar incorporated into their commander card, or one of the statistics that shows up on one of the world_map overlay panels.
A player gains by performing actions. For example, winning a battle might grant the player a good amount of , and even losing a battle might grant a fraction of that . Successfully crafting something should yield , and failing a crafting attempt should grant a fraction of that . Anything that takes effort on the player's part should grant , and in contrast, simple things like equipping soldier or mining should not grant any .
One minor exception to the latter rule should be that a player can give kovanite to their faction in exchange for , among other things.
feature.impact: serves as the universal progress tracker. When a player gains , they know they're progressing in the game, and it should motivate them to continue doing whatever it is they were doing to gain in the first place.

feature.title: Faction

goals.goal: Provide a 'side' for the Player to fight for.
Allow friends to join the same team and play towards the same goals.
Allow anyone to distinguish easily between the different sides based on color, pattern, logo silhouette, or any combination.

feature.background:
The three (3)
within the game are:
The Interplanetary Kova Company (IKC)
A defense powerhouse, responsible for a substantial part of Earth's arms trade. War is an eventuality on Earth, and the need for weapons never waivered. The IKC is fighting to secure a steady supply of kovanite to its factories on Earth to support the armies of the future. The IKC is responsible for designing most of the weapon used by commander of all faction on setting.
Ekova, Inc. (EKV)
A family-owned industrialist corporation responsible for many of Earth's environmentally friendly advances. Ekova handles many of Earth's major metropolitan infrastructure contracts, building roads, apartments, parks, and many other civil installations. Ekova uses Kovanite in many of its projects, and has a vested interest in its continued export from Kova to Earth, preferrably via its own transport ships to internal storage facilities. Ekova is responsible for designing most of the vehicles used by commanders on Kova, including the standard mcc.
Kovanant (KVN)
A rogue, technology-obsessed umbrella corporation fighting to take absolute control over setting and turn it into a space-faring utopia. Many of its subsidiaries on Earth are simply buffer companies used to filter money around the planet and especially offworld to support its military engagements on setting itself. Kovanant is responsible for many of the device used by soldier on setting.
feature.implementation:
There are three (3)
within the game, and upon signing up the player must choose one to join. The decision is permanent, so the player cannot switch
later on. On the select screen, it should be readily apparent whether or not they have friends playing for a specific , or all 3 if that happens to be the case. The player should also be able to see specifically which of their friends is on which .
Each is distinguished by a color, a pattern, and a logo, where each color is easily discernable from the next, more than likely Red, Blue, and Yellow for the most accessibility. Each logo should also be easily recognizable by its silhouette alone. When a 's color is painted anywhere, it should be painted in that 's pattern, for example dashed lines, curvy lines, circles, etc. Each pattern should also be easily distinguishable.
Each player should also have a fnn panel on the screen that pulls in broadcasts from their , giving them small tidbits of story development.
feature.impact:
provide animosity for players, meaning a player from one wants to defeat players from other
, so it gives all players on one a unified goal: to promote and progress their while hindering enemy
. A should also provide benefits to its players, depending on the throughput of kovaite or other resources and equipment, meaning if players substantially contribute to their 's success, either by winning battle and securing territory, or sending sufficient kovanite back to the , the players should receive perks relative to their actions, such as attack bonuses, equipment, or any temporary improvements to any of the actions they may perform in the game.

feature.title: Mobile Command Center

goals.goal: Provide a representation in game for the player's location
Provide a practical means to restrict the player's ability to move soldier quickly around the world_map
Provide a practical means to restrict the player's ability to mine for resource in only one zone
Accomodate alternative play styles

feature.background: The Arpa9 All-Terrain Support Center and Skyvault Self-Levitating Airbase were inventions of the late Terrance Bilsner, former CEO of Ekova, Inc. The Arpa9, at first, was primarly used for supporting construction crews as they built transcontinental high-speed rail lines across Siberian Russia, but the gigantic machines proved to be incredibly useful in the acquisition of kovanite. Resourceful commander retrofitted the machines with workshop and warehouse to help in the outfitting and supply of armies on the surface of setting.
feature.implementation:
A can either be 'Flying' or 'Rolling', which is to say one flies through the air and one rolls over the ground. The player chooses which they would like to control when they first sign up. The is also what holds all of the player's soldier, equipment, vehicle, and resource. The is always stationed within a zone inside a territory, and the player's first starts out in a random zone within their faction_headquarters.
The is always mobile, meaning the player can move it around the world_map. Moving is not always instant, however, with Rolling
, unless the use of a faction_dropship is employed. Without a faction_dropship, it could take a few hours for a to move from one territory to another. When a is in motion, it is essentially not stationed anywhere until the move is complete. A player can only move their to a zone that is controlled by their faction. If the target zone is taken over by an enemy faction while the is in motion, it will instantly return to a random zone within the player's faction_headquarters. The 's position on the map also determines how long it takes soldier to travel to their target battle if faction_dropship are not used.
Flying
are a little different than their Rolling counterparts. Flying
do not need to use faction_dropship, as they can instantly move between territory. Flying
have no room for soldier, which means commander controlling a Flying will never directly engage in battle. Instead, Flying
provide a support role to their faction and friends. Flying
get a significant bonus to mining, meaning they can pull up resource much faster, which also gives them an advantage in crafting. Players using a Flying also have exclusive access to sell items on the marketplace, which players using a Rolling cannot.
Travel between zone in the same territory is instant regardless of what type of a player is using.
feature.impact:
The mainly provides a physical manifestation of the player on the world_map. Wherever the is stationed is where the player can mine for resource, and the location affects travel times for squads of soldier to their target battle.
Having two different types of
allows for two completely different playstyles. Players who enjoy direct conflict should employ a Rolling , and players who enjoy crafting or simply supporting their friends would use a Flying .

feature.title: Faction Dropship

goals.goal: Impose a restriction on the player to keep them from being able to perform too many move commands in a short time period

feature.implementation:
The player is provided with a small number of tokens that they can turn over for the use of a . A can transport mcc and soldier. Travel using a is instant, where otherwise it may take minutes or hours for a player to move an object across the world_map. The player should not have to take any special actions to use a . When the player selects a button or menu item to perform a move or attack action, if the player has tokens left, a box should pop up asking them if they want a lift from their faction. If they say yes, the action is performed instantly, otherwise the action takes however long it would normally take.
The players tokens should replenish over time. Beginning players below a certain rank should have access to unlimited
.
feature.impact: serve to limit the player's ability to perform a lot of move actions in a small timeframe. This way, say a player is out of tokens, and they want to move their mcc to a different territory with a good resource distribution. Without tokens, they have to wait a while, so they can't instantly reap the benefits being over a good zone.

feature.title: World Map

goals.goal: Provide a global scale for the game.
Allow the player to easily see the entire game map, and the major events taking place within it.

feature.background: setting is made up of a single major landmass, with many small outlying islands, but the major concentration of valuable resource lies in the center of the continent. The landscape is Earth-like, with rolling hills, mountains, valleys, forests, and plains, but only flora and minor, unintelligent fauna live on the planet's surface.
feature.implementation:
The is where the player manages the locations of all of their actions. They can see a full view off all of the territory in the game, which ones are disputed, which ones their faction is defending, and which ones their faction is attacking. Each of the territory is color coded, depending on which faction currently holds the territory. Some territory may not be occupied, in which case their color will not reflect any of the faction.
Some territory are clickable, namely territory owned by the player's faction and open enemy territory next to territory owned by the player's faction. When the player clicks on one, a radial menu pops up with the following potential options (not all will show up, depending on the status and owner):
An icon allowing them to zoom into the territory to view its zones
The overlay of the world map should include most of the information vital to the player's gameplay, including:
The number of dropship_credit the player has left
The commander's current experience level, and an indicator of how much experience the player still needs to get before the commander achieves the next rank
The used and unused bandwidth of the player's mcc
The total number of credit in their bank
A link to the workshop
A link to the warehouse
A link to the marketplace
A link or small section dedicated to the player's mail
Either a link or small portion of the screen dedicated to the fnn
A small portion of the screen dedicated to notification
feature.impact: The is the center of the global conflict in the game. It allows the player to easily see where the action is, and allows them to easily jump into it. The also serves as the initial entry point for the game. It is the first screen the player sees when logging in, and links through to all of the major actions the player can perform within the game.

feature.title: Territory

goals.goal: Provide defined areas of the world_map that players can fight to control

feature.implementation:
A is an individual region on the world_map. When the player clicks a , a new window will transition in showing them statistics about that and a map of the zone within it. The information about a that is publicly available to a player should be:
Whether or not the is disputed. It's disputed if there are currently battles going on within it, so the player should also be able to see which zone have battles active within them.
If the is controlled by the player's faction, there may be friendly mcc stationed within the , so the player should see how many there are and which zone they're stationed in.
In contrast, if the is controlled by an enemy faction, there may be enemy mcc stationed within the , so if the is currently open to attack from the player, or is currently disputed by the player's faction, they should be able to see how many enemy mcc there are, and where they are on the map.
control works on a timed sequence of events. If more than one faction's
are adjacent to one another on the world map, and neither is currently in a 'locked' state, those
are concidered to be 'open.' Any player from any of the adjoining faction can attack an enemy faction's open at will, and once the first battle starts within a after it has been opened, the becomes 'disputed.' Players from any of the faction participating in the dispute can attack individual zone within the . After the becomes disputed, a timer is started and should be visible to players within the view, showing them how long until the dispute is automatically resolved. While the timer is running, players attempt to gain control of a majority of the zone within the , and once the timer is complete, the faction with the most controlled zone is awarded the . Once a dispute is resolved, the goes into a 'lock' state, and cannot be attacked for a small period of time.
If the is currently controlled by the player's faction and they click on a zone, an option should pop up allowing them to station their mcc on that zone. This action should be rank restricted, meaning if a player is below a certain rank, they may only move their mcc around within their faction_headquarters, and can't move to other
until they achieve the proper rank.
A also determines the resource distributions in the zone it contains. The farther a is from all of the faction_headquarters, the better the quality of resource a player will get from its zone while mining.

feature.title: Faction Headquarters

goals.goal: Provide a representation for a faction's base of operations on the world_map
To give new and old players alike a safe haven, and an important place to protect

feature.implementation:
Each faction has a territory on the world_map that serves as their . The should be clearly defined from the player's perspective on the world_map. The , in general, works exactly like a normal territory with the exception that enemy faction cannot attack it. All beginning players start out on the territory, and are not allowed to leave until they reach a specific rank. Within the are the same number of zone as in a normal territory.
The also affects the global resource distribution, meaning zone within territory that are close to a will have low quality resource, especially zone within the itself, and zone within territory that are far away from all of the
will have better quality resource.
feature.impact: The serves as a safe haven for new players that have just joined the faction. Players are free to move their mcc around within the ' borders, and mine the resource within. This gives new players a sort of training ground to learn the basics of the game without actually venturing out into the world and having to deal with the hardships that more experienced players go through.

feature.title: Zone

goals.goal: Divide a territory into small regions to make it more difficult to capture it from an enemy faction
Create a more diverse resource distribution

feature.implementation:
are the regions within a territory. When a player clicks on a , one of two things happens. If the territory that the zone is in is disputed, and the belongs to an enemy faction or is currently being attacked by an enemy faction, a new screen transitions in with a localized map view of the , and a few scenario dotted around it. The number of scenario is randomized and changes every time the containing territory becomes open to attack. At this point the player can choose a scenario to participate in, or zoom back out.
If the is controlled by the player's faction, clicking on the brings up a simple radial menu. The menu should include a set of options depending on what the player can do, including:
An option to move the player's mcc to this if they're of sufficient rank
An option to bring up a panel with this 's resource distribution
have a resource distribution that is determined partly by the containing territory's distance from each faction_headquarters, and partly by random. The 's resource distribution should be refreshed every so often.

feature.title: Scenario

goals.goal: Provide several different battle within a zone that players must complete to gain control of that zone

feature.implementation:
zone are divided up into different
. The number of
within a zone varies, changing each time the parent territory becomes open to attack.
are only visible when a territory is open to attack. Some
may be occupied, as only one battle can be going on within a at a time, and some
may be locked, as once a has been won by a particular faction, it remains locked until the parent territory dispute is resolved and subsequently opens up to attack again. By this mechanism, once all
in a zone are locked, the zone itself becomes locked until the next attack cycle. When a player clicks on an available, unlocked, unoccupied within a zone owned by an enemy faction, a simple menu pops up asking them if they would like to enter. If the zone is owned by the player's faction, they may only click on
that have enemy squads already within or en route. If the player confirms, a spot in that for them is reserved. Afterwards, a screen pops up allowing them to select which soldier they would like to send to the . This can be done later if the player wishes to outfit their squad first. A simple way to return to the deployment screen should be available from the world_map, should the player not wish to immediately deploy their squad. If the player chooses to deploy a squad to the , but does not do so within a certain time period, their reserved position in the will be given up.
After the player selects the squad they would like to send to the , they are either allowed to use a faction_dropship to send their squad in immediately, or manually send the squad in on one of the mcc's small shuttles, which could take a while depending on how far the player's mcc is stationed from the target territory. After all players who have reserved a position in the send their squads in, they must wait for all squads to arrive. Currently the plan is to only allow a maximum of 2 players in each , which means only two faction can fight over a specific .
Once all players' squads have arrived at the target , a new battle begins. Additionally, should a player who sends their squad in manually choose to not partake in the battle, they may retract their squad, giving up their position in the in the process.
If all three faction have an interest in a territory, meaning two faction own a territory that's next to a third faction's open territory, it's possible that all 3 faction could be fighting within the same territory. In this case, it's possible that within a single zone, a stalemate could occur if there are 3
and each has been locked by a different faction. If this event happens, all of the
unlock, with the zone still under control of the original owning faction. If all
within the zone are locked, the zone is awarded to the faction with the most locked
If a player sends a squad to a within an enemy owned zone, a timer begins once the squad arrives. If no battle begins over the before the timer ends, the locks, with the player who sent the squad essentially 'winning' the . Once a battle begins, however, that timer is rendered null, and a player must win the battle for the to lock.
feature.impact:
give a lot of versatility to the way territory change hands within the game. If each is slightly different, either in play style or terrain type or map, or anything really, it makes it so taking over each zone is a different experience for players. Taking over one zone might only require completing 2
, whereas another zone may require completing 5 or 6
. If each represents a different game type within the battle, it could also allow players who enjoy one type of strategy game but not another to pick and choose their battle and only partake in the games that they like, and let other players handle the rest.

feature.title: Faction News Network

goals.goal: Provide an outlet for the player to get story-progressing material from their faction

feature.implementation: When the player views the , it really just needs to be a list of broadcasts seemingly coming from the player's faction_headquarters. At a regular interval, new blog posts, videos, or images should be posted to the in order to keep a continuous narrative running for the player.
feature.impact: The is an outlet to help continue the story of Boomtown, by providing players of each faction a continuous stream of stories, videos, and images of their faction and the stories behind its leadership.

feature.title: Notification

goals.goal: Give a standardized way to notify players about actions in the game that affect them but that they did not personally perform

feature.implementation:
should show up in their own section on the world_map, clearly visible, and depending on the importance of the , blinking, or doing something that will surely grab the player's attention.
will essentially be a history of events that affect the player but that the player did not initiate. Some examples of notifications could be:
An enemy player has made a move in a battle that the player is participating in
An enemy faction has taken over a zone that the player's mcc is stationed in
A friend of the player has just entered into a battle
should have differentiating characteristics, or classes, so the player can clearly pick out the most vital
over minor ones that don't require action. The different classes could be:
battle: a having to do with a battle that the player is currently participating in
marketplace: a having to do with an item on the marketplace, maybe the player won it in an auction or successfully sold it
soldier: a having to do with one of the player's soldier, maybe they have fully regenerated or all of their training_point have run out
territory: a having to do with the current zone the player is on, maybe the resource distribution changed in the player's current zone, or the zone or territory is disputed or is no longer controlled by the player's faction
equipment: a having to do with equipment the player owns, perhaps a crafting operation finished, or maybe an item's durability degraded and the item was destroyed, or maybe a faction's kovanite meter filled up and the player is awarded an item
feature.impact: Since Boomtown is a slow, turn-based game, things may happen to the player's commander while the player is not logged in or actively playing, so there needs to be a way to clearly notify the player of all important, relevant events that happened in the world since they last logged in.

feature.title: Warehouse

goals.goal: Provide the player with a central place to manage all of their assets

feature.implementation:
The is linked from the world_map. The is all one screen, but broken up into sections.
Along the bottom of the screen, in a tabbed layout, is the equipment management panel. It should be a sideways scrolling grid of the equipment that a player owns that is not currently attached to a soldier or vehicle. Each piece of equipment takes up a certain amount of grid space. The left side of the screen should be taken up by a statistics box, and when a player clicks on a piece of equipment, its statistics and ability, and maybe a better image of the piece should show up in the statistics box. To the right of the equipment grid should be a 'trash' area, and the player should be able to click and drag pieces of equipment into it. A small question mark or button in the 'trash' area should explain to the player that when they 'trash' a piece of equipment it removes it from their possession permanently and puts it on the marketplace for a cheap price.
The has limited amount of space for equipment, indicated by a weight capacity ratio somewhere near the equipment panel. The player is allowed to go one item over the capacity, but after the total weight of all the player's equipment surpasses the weight capacity, they are no longer allowed to perform actions that add equipment to their inventory, and any involuntary actions that would give the player items would see those items disappear. resource and soldier do not contribute to the 's weight capacity.
The top of the screen should have a soldier listing. Similar to the equipment listing, it should be a grid layout, only with one row. Each soldier should be represented by a square block with an image that represents them. The soldier listing should be split in two. The left listing should only have enlisted soldier, or soldier that the player has already recruited, and the right list should only have potential recruits that the player may acquire. When a player clicks on a potential recruit, only their attributes should show up in the statistics box, as their skills will be at default levels. Additionally, two buttons should show up in the statistics box that let the player either recruit the soldier, or pass on them and remove them from the potential recruit pool. If the player chooses to recruit a new soldier, a new box should pop up allowing them to choose which skill they would like to specialize the soldier in. When a player clicks on a recruited soldier, their attributes and skill should show up in the statistics box, and in the main part of the screen, a representation of the soldier should show up, with equipment slots around it for dragging items in and equipping them on the soldier. The different slots should include:
Head armor
Body armor
Leg armor
Left-hand weapon
Right-hand weapon
Backpack
The armor slots cover a basic representation of a soldier, so the player drags armor pieces onto the head, body, and legs of the representation to equip those pieces. The other slots should just be boxes covering the general area of the soldier that they are associated with, the left hand being near the left arm, right hand being near the right arm, and backpack being somewhere near the shoulders. Each slot can only receive one piece of equipment, the armor slots can only receive armor, the weapon slots can only receive weapon, and the backpack slot can only receive device.
If the player clicks on a vehicle, an equipping screen specific to that vehicle should show up in the main part of the screen, and the vehicles statistics should show up like a normal piece of equipment in the statistics box. Additionally, in the equipping side of the screen, depending on the size of the vehicle and the number of soldier it requires to operate, there should be that many boxes sized for soldier that the player can drag them into to assign them to the vehicle.
feature.impact: The is the main hub where the player manages their assets. In the , the player outfits their soldier, inspects their equipment, and recruits new soldier. It is meant to be a place the player spends a lot of time before sending squads of soldier out to battle.

feature.title: Marketplace

goals.goal: Provide a means for players to acquire items from other players that they may not have the resource available to craft themselves
Provide support players a way to gain money and experience and make a name for themselves via crafting exceptional equipment and selling it

feature.implementation:
The is accessed via the world_map, and consists of a main screen with either one tab (in which case it's just one screen), or two tabs if a player is controlling a Flying mcc. The first tab is the 'Buy' tab, which lists pieces of equipment available to buy that other players have listed. It should be catagorized by equipment type, and probably searchable. When a player clicks on an available piece, its equipment card should pop up showing the player its statistics. Additionally there should be a 'Buy' button on the listing, and if the player clicks it a confirmation pops up asking them if they're sure they would like to buy it. If they click yes, the piece is transferred to their mcc's warehouse and is immediately available to them. Each piece of equipment has a credit value associated with it that will be taken out of the player's bank if they decide to buy that piece.
Additionally, support players controlling a Flying mcc are given access to the 'Sell' tab. The screen should list the player's current inventory of equipment, categorized by type, and when the player clicks on a piece of equipment a screen pops up allowing them to set a price for it and add it to the . When the player adds a piece to the , it is removed from the player's inventory until it either sells, or the player removes it from the .
Sellers should have access to sale metrics of whatever piece of equipment they're trying to sell, meaning a chart or list or something of the prices the specific piece sold for within some time period.
feature.impact: The will be the center of the game's economy. The mainly gives support players a place to make a lot of money to either advance their crafting or support their friends. Beginning players will also find the useful for finding beginning equipment that Flying mcc operators have made, or that Rolling mcc have 'trashed'.

feature.title: Mail

goals.goal: Provide a way for players to send messages, equipment, resource, and credit to one another

feature.implementation:
A player's is accessed from the world_map, and new messages show up as notification. When the player accesses their , a mailbox of sorts should show up, with a list of recently received messages, and a button to allow the player to send a new message. If the player decides to send a new message, they should be able to title it, and type in a body message. Additionally, there should be a field or slider allowing the player to send credit along with the message, and another box that lets them browse for resource or equipment to send along with the message.
Should the player decide to send equipment, they should be able to specify that a return message needs to be received and confirmed before the transaction takes place, meaning if player A sends some equipment to player B and wants something in return, either credit or resource or some other type of equipment, player A can flag his or her message as needing a confirmed response, so that when player B sends back a response, player A can either cancel the entire transaction, or confirm that an acceptable message was received and complete the transaction. In this manner, until player A confirms the transaction, neither player receives the items in the message.
faction does not play a role in sending messages. Players from one faction can still send messages to players of another.
feature.impact:
Friends may want to send friends credit or old equipment, or maybe resource to help with crafting, so the system allows them to communicate in a basic way and send these things back and forth easily.
I'll note here, it is intended that players use outside methods of communication to coordinate things with friends and form guilds and the like, making in-game chat or things like that unnecessary.

feature.title: Credit

goals.goal: Provide players a commoddity with which they can purchase items from the marketplace
Provide a way for players to expedite certain actions in the game

feature.implementation:
Any time a player needs to pay for anything, whether it potentially be equipment repairs if they're implemented, items on the marketplace, or any of the other various services that may be offered to the player, it will be paid for in

feature.title: Workshop

goals.goal: Give the player a central place to manage resource gathering and crafting operations.

feature.implementation:
The is linked from the world_map. The consists of one main screen and a few modal screens accessible via buttons.
When the player first visits the , a large part of the left side of the screen should be taken up with mining management. A panel should show what the player is currently mining, the resource distribution of the zone their mcc is currently stationed on, and buttons to allow the player to change which resource the player wants to acquire. A progress bar should also show how long until the next batch of resource will be pulled up.
The right side of the screen should be taken up by a grid layout showing the player what current resource they have in their possession. Each resource should have an icon, and number representing the quantity.
The bottom of the screen should be the crafting interface. It doesn't need to be very big, mostly just a large space to indicate the current crafting processes, and a button to open the crafting table. On the left side of the panel should be a grid layout where current processes can go. Each item in the grid should have an icon of what's being created, a progress bar indicating how much longer it has to complete, and the title of whatever's being created. On the right of the panel should be a button that when clicked launches the crafting window.

feature.title: Soldier

goals.goal: Provide the player with unique, customizable units to do battle with
Provide the player with enough differentiation between each unit so that they can devise strategies based on their unit differences

feature.background:
Due to the advent of cloning sometime around the turn of the century, war is now fought by cloned
, grown in tanks aboard the Arpa9 mcc, bred toward different goals and skill sets. A clone, from the point of creation in a test tube, takes less than a day to fully mature, and in that time it's possible to implant special skillset subroutines deep within its brain, essentially training it in whatever the grower wishes. All clones are not built the same, however, and occasionaly mutations in the cloning process create exceptional specimens, or worthless specimens, depending on luck.
feature.implementation:
A is the player's primary battle unit. Players manage their
in the warehouse, outfitting them with equipment and assigning them to vehicle.
All
are essentially the same. They have a set of attributes, and they have a list of skill. The attributes a has include:
Health - Determines the number of hp the has
Accuracy - Affects the base accuracy of any weapon the may use
Perception - Affects the 's line of sight distance and stealth detection
Stealth - Affects the 's visibility on the battlefield
The attributes work on a total point system, meaning a gets a set number of attribute points, and upon creation those points are distributed randomly between the attributes. For example, if we allot 40 attribute points to each , one particular might have 17 Health, 5 Accuracy, 10 Perception, and 8 Stealth, and another might have 5 Health, 20 Accuracy, 9 Perception, and 6 Stealth. The first might make an excellent heavy weapons operator, and the second would make an excellent sniper.
Health is a direct representation of the 's hp, or the points taken away when the is successfully attacked. Each point of Health represents an arbitrary number of hp. For example, if each point of Health is the equivalent of 5 hp, and one has 12 Health points, they would have 60 hp in total.
Perception and Stealth are counter attributes, meaning a with high Stealth will not be visible to a with low Perception until they are either right next to them, or fire their weapon. This means that regardless if a can see 12 tiles ahead of them, if they have low Perception, they may not be able to see enemy
with high Stealth until those enemies are within 3 tiles. If one attacks another , all Stealth modifiers are eliminated. A with a high Stealth rating would be better employed as a close-combat fighter, or a sniper.
Additionally,
have a set of skill that they can train up.

feature.title: Equipment

goals.goal: The player needs a vast array of different items to attach to their soldier to customize their battle ability

feature.implementation:
All items in the game that a soldier can use or operate are just pieces of . weapon, armor, device, and vehicle are all . A given piece of has a type, one of the before-mentioned things, a set of attributes depending on its type, and in some cases, modifier ability. All pieces of have a Durability attribute, a number out of 100 representing its wear and tear. As the piece is used, its Durability rating will go down. If its Durability reaches 0, it is irreversably destroyed. A player can pay credit to have the item repaired.
Any given piece of may have modifier ability assigned to it, meaning that when a soldier equips that particular piece, the soldier is able to use those ability in battle. The modifier ability are determined during the crafting process, so not all instances of a particular piece will have all of the same ability. Each individual piece of has its own set of possible modifier ability that can be applied during the crafting process.
All comes from the crafting process. No is ever looted, or spawned as a reward for something. The only way a player can acquire is by crafting it, or buying it from the marketplace.
